acf.name: Combi Boiler
acf.description: A combi boiler provides heat for your radiators and domestic hot water on demand.

pros.heading: More Efficient
pros.body: Combi boilers are highly efficient when compared to older boiler models. In fact, replacing your boiler with a newer combi boiler could help you to save up to £300 a year on your heating bills.

pros.heading: Cheaper
pros.body: Combi boilers are far less complex than traditional heating systems, which means that installations tend to be cheaper. It is also easier to find replacement parts if a problem occurs.

pros.heading: Faster
pros.body: With no water tank to heat up, combi boilers can provide an unlimited supply of hot water on demand. No waiting time!

pros.heading: More Compact
pros.body: As there is no need for a separate water tank, combi boiler systems take up much less space than conventional heating systems. This makes them ideal for homes that have limited room.

pros.heading: Safer
pros.body: The cold water from a combi boiler system is always safe to drink as it is fed directly from the mains. However, this is not always true of traditional systems, which may store cold water in a tank before it is piped through the house.

pros.heading: Easier to Sell
pros.body: As combi boiler tend to be more efficient that other boiler types, this can be a selling point if you are looking to rent or sell your property. This will also show on the Energy Performance Certificate (EPC).

cons.heading: Dependence on Mains Pressure
cons.body: To ensure that your combi boiler is working properly, you need good mains pressure. If you are having a new boiler fitted, you should check what the mains pressure is before you go ahead with the installation.

cons.heading: Limited Use
cons.body: With a combi boiler it is not possible to run more than one shower or bath at a time, or to turn on the hot tap while showering. This may be an issue if you live in a large house with a number of bathrooms and en suites, or with lots of people.

cons.heading: No Immersion Heater
cons.body: As there is no water tank, if your combi boiler breaks down then you will be left without hot water as well as central heating (unless you install an electric shower).

acf.name: Biomass Boiler
acf.description: Wood-fuelled heating systems, or biomass systems, burn varieties of wood to either warm a single room or to provide central heating and hot water.

acf.name: Micro CHP Boiler
acf.description: Micro combined heat and power (micro-CHP) is a technology which generates heat and electricity simultaneously.

acf.name: Solar water heater
acf.description: Solar water heating systems, or 'solar thermal' systems, use free heat from the sun to warm domestic hot water.

acf.name: Ground source heat pump
acf.description: Ground source heat pumps (GSHPs) use pipes that are buried in the garden to extract heat from the ground.
acf.space_requirement: Space for the pipes (underground in a garden of at least 400 square metres) and the heat pump (a small room or outbuilding)

acf.name: Air source heat pump
acf.description: Air source heat pumps (ASHPs) absorb heat from the outside air and use it to heat your home.

acf.name: Regular Boiler
acf.description: Regular boilers (also known as 'conventional' boilers) heat your central heating system directly and produce hot water for your cylinder.
acf.space_requirement: Room for cylinder (a full-length cupboard) and tank (a loft or very large cupboard)

acf.name: System Boiler
acf.description: A system boiler has components housed externally from the boiler and will normally require cold water, as well as feed and expansion tanks in the loft.
